resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key priorities following the 2019 European elections, noting a 50.66% voter turnout—the highest in 20 years—driven by youth engagement (over 50% motivated by climate urgency and civic duty) but marked by disparities among Member States and high abstention rates. It highlighted the need to address barriers for marginalized groups, including 800,000 citizens with disabilities disenfranchised by national laws and 700,000 homeless people facing voting access challenges. Gender representation improved to 41% women MEPs, though imbalances persist across states. The resolution criticized the failure of the Spitzenkandidaten process to secure the Commission Presidency, urging reforms by 2024 to enhance transparency and voter awareness, alongside proposals for transnational lists, harmonized electoral rules (including lowering the voting age to 16), and a unified European electoral law. It called for combating foreign interference and disinformation through increased funding, media literacy, and an independent ethics body, while advocating for a European Electoral Authority to oversee electoral integrity. The Parliament emphasized strengthening European political parties via campaign finance transparency, visibility on ballots, and pan-European debates, and endorsed the Conference on the Future of Europe to address institutional reforms, such as transforming the Council into a legislative chamber. Additional measures included improving accessibility for Roma communities, harmonizing voter registration deadlines, and ensuring media coverage of EU issues to reinforce democratic engagement.

title: The UK’s withdrawal from the EU: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the state of play of the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union | B9-0038/2019 | European Parliament

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical importance of an orderly UK withdrawal to mitigate negative consequences, emphasizing the Withdrawal Agreement as a fair and balanced solution safeguarding citizens’ rights, the Irish border, and financial obligations. The resolution underscored the necessity of the backstop to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland, protect the Good Friday Agreement, and maintain the all-island economy, noting its temporary nature but rejecting removal without legally operational alternatives. It expressed concern over UK proposals for regulatory divergence and no-deal preparations, warning of disproportionate economic harm to the UK, and affirmed EU unity. resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical need for enhanced transparency, democratic accountability, and parliamentary scrutiny in implementing the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF), emphasizing the Commission’s obligation to regularly inform Parliament on the status of national recovery and resilience plans, including reforms and investments aligned with the RRF’s six pillars and 11 assessment criteria. It highlighted that 18 Member States had submitted their plans by the resolution’s adoption, with the Commission required to assess each within two months, and urged timely approval of delegated acts on the recovery scoreboard and social expenditure methodology before the summer recess. Parliament stressed the importance of accessible, comparable information formats, translations of national documents, and preliminary findings on milestones and targets prior to their formal assessment. It called for robust stakeholder consultations at national levels, particularly involving local authorities, civil society, and social partners, as mandated by Article 18(4)(q) of the RRF Regulation, and insisted on full transparency in the Commission’s dialogue with Parliament to uphold democratic legitimacy and citizen ownership of the RRF. The resolution also reminded the Council to share relevant preparatory discussions with Parliament and urged the Commission to maintain an open, constructive approach throughout the recovery and resilience dialogue.
